title: What's the difference between rock and stone? - Quora

response.answer_text: A few ways to look at this (original intent of question at the bottom) Music Stone: die hard fan of the Rolling Stones, no one is even close to their artistry and mastery to you. Rock(er): You love all kinds of rock music Human biology You can’t have kidney rocks. Motions You can ‘rock’ back and forth, which is similar to the motion a pendulum makes, only upside down. Stoning is either the medieval and BC practice of throwing stones at people in order to kill them (normally as punishment for breaking the law) or it is getting high on marijuana. WWE Stone: Stone Cold Steve Austin Rock: Dwayne ‘The Rock’ Johnson Geology Stones tend to be of a certain size, something you can hold in your hand but that isn’t too big to throw. They also tend to be a specific shape, like a disc, sphere, or cube. Essentially they are a sort of “ideal” rock. (This is not a scientific definition because ‘stone’ is not a scientific term. Also, you can have stones that are too large to throw but those are always referred to as “large stones” or “huge stones”) Rocks on the other hand range from microscopic fragments to huge ‘rocks’ like the famous Uluru in australia:  Rocks also tend to be made up of many different minerals, where as stones might be made up of only one mineral, like ‘precious stones’ such as ruby and sapphire (although fun fact: rubies are actually still sapphires, they just have a red color). Neither of them are ever just one element, except in the case of the ‘precious stone’ of diamond, which is pure carbon.

There is no practical difference between a rock and a stone. Different words for the same thing - something English is very good at. Usually we would use ‘rock’ for any random rock - bedrock, river rock, rock wall - and use ‘stone’ for rocks people have taken to use, and SHAPED - like ‘stone edging’ or ‘cobble stones’ or something like that. So a ‘rock wall’ would be made of rocks people picked up and stacked, and a ‘stone wall’ would be made of rocks people had picked up and knocked the edges off a bit to shape them and THEN stacked. But that’s getting pretty picky, and it isn’t like anybody polices the use of the terms ‘rock’ and ‘stone’. Feel free to use them interchangeably. Still - a rock is something sitting on the ground. But if you pick up that same rock and throw it at somebody, it’s a stone.

Rock To the geologist any mass of mineral matter, whether consolidated or not, which forms a part of the crustThe engineer regards rock as something hard, consolidated, and/or load bearing, which, where necessary, has got to be removed by blasting.A rock is bigger, possibly immovable; you couldn't throw it with one hand, at a pinch you might be able to with two.Stone In geology the word 'stone' is admissible only in combinations like limestone, sandstone, etc. or where it's used because the name for extracted material - building stone, stone road. It shouldn't be used as a synonym for rock or pebble.Stone is (uncountable) a hard earthen substance that can form large rocks and boulders.A stone is formed from rocks after it has been trimmed or dressed or polished into tiny pieces.

The terms refer to the same thing but like the term limestone or hard rock or volcanic rock can have a slightly different context to their makeup. Igneous rock forms from the melting of magma but limestone forms from precipitation of CaCO3 from water and the evaporation of water. Stone in general usually refers to a building material that can be used to build something but rock is usually a more general term and describes something hard that may or may not be used to build something. The difference between the two terms is based more upon how they were originally named or used rather than the material they are made of.

The terms rock and stone are used interchangeably and have a similar meaning, but there is a difference between them. On the basis of size, a stone is much smaller than a rock. In simpler terms, it means that rock is made out of stone and mineral matter. The stone is used for construction is cut out of ricks; rocks are mainly found on the earth's crust and is found on the surface of the earth. On the contrary, stone can be considered as non-metallic minerals. For stone supplies in OKC, make sure to contact your nearest stone supplier today!

You should take a look at: Orion Montoya's answer to What is the difference between stone and rock and how should I use them in a sentence? It's a very good answer. I'll quote a little of it:  "Rock more typically denotes the raw material that the planet earth is made of, especially in unfinished form; stone often denotes the material of an object that has been (or is intended to be) shaped by humans."

The differences that come to mind are : a rock has a formal definition in geology but I am not sure a stone does;the word stone is commonly used for something that is of an appropriate size to be held in your hand, the way most people use the term rock it has no size connotation;the vocabulary of the person speaking;The terms are essentially synonymous. Not much of an answer but that is all I know about it.

Interesting question. Not using a dictionary, to me a rock equals a gemstone that I can Facet. Many faceters I know are not gemologists. Many gemologists I have met can't Facet a gemstone. I and others call ourselves rock cutters. Gem quality rocks. A stone is used in gravel driveways. But, someone else will give you dictionary answer you might like better.

Honestly, I don’t know if there is any sort of scientific or geologic answer for this question, but when you say “rock” a rough, jagged and pointy rock comes to mind. When you say “stone” a smooth, oblong, shiny stone comes to mind. That’s just me though.
